name: Avoid database tables associated to more than one Hibernate Entity
description:
An entity models a database table
This rule checks if used database tables are associated to more than one Hibernate Entity. If yes, a violation is reported except for 
- Entities that belong to the same hierarchy and that are stored into a single table using the table-per-class-hierarchy strategy (also know as SINGLE_TABLE in JPA) 
and 
- Entities that are stored into several tables using table-per-sub-class strategy (also know as JOINED in JPA).

Note that in the case where two hierarchy are associated to the same table, only the root Entity will be reported, not all the hierarchy.
output:
List all Entities that reference the same table.
It provides the following information:
- Entity Full Name 
- table name
rationale:
One main source of data corruption within applications comes from lack of compliance to data modification rules defined for an application. These rules are usually related to the use of specific procedures for update/insert/delete, a specific API or a data layer that is fully tested to maintain data integrity. The creation of new, different update/insert/delete procedures and functions that do not make use the existing tested code is at origin of many data corruption cases.
In the case of Hibernate, having different mapping files associated with the same table is a source of such data corruption.
remediation: Review your design and decide which Entity must manage the table.
alternativeName: Ensure that each database table is associated to only one Hibernate Entity in order avoid data corruption.
